speaker: moderator
text: Good evening and welcome to the NBC News Youtube Democratic candidate's debate. After all the campaigning, soon, Americans will have their say with the first votes of the 2016 campaign just 15 days away in Iowa. And New Hampshire not far behind.

speaker: moderator
text: Tonight will be the final opportunity to see these candidates face to face before the voting begins. Our purpose here tonight is to highlight and examine the differences among the three Democratic candidates. So let's get started.

speaker: moderator
text: Please welcome Secretary Hillary Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders and Governor Martin O'Malley. [applause]

speaker: moderator
text: Well, welcome to all of you. Hope you're excited, we're excited.

speaker: moderator
text: We want to thank our hosts, the Congressional Black Caucus Institute. I'm joined by my colleague Andrea Mitchell tonight.

speaker: moderator
text: The rules are simple. Sixty seconds for answers, 30 seconds for follow-ups or rebuttals. I know you'll all keep exactly to time, so our job should be pretty easy here tonight.

speaker: moderator
text: We'll have questions from the Youtube community throughout the debate.

speaker: moderator
text: This is a critical point in the race. You've been defining your differences with each other especially vigorously in the last week on the campaign trail.

speaker: moderator
text: We're here to facilitate this conversation on behalf of the voters so that they know exactly where you stand as you face off tonight. Let's have a great debate.

speaker: moderator
text: We'll begin with 45 second opening statements from each candidate, starting with Secretary Clinton.

speaker: clinton
text: Well, good evening. And I want to thank the Congressional Black Caucus Institute and the people of Charleston for hosting us here on the eve of Martin Luther King Day tomorrow.

speaker: clinton
text: You know, I remember well when my youth minister took me to hear Dr. King. I was a teenager.

speaker: clinton
text: And his moral clarity, the message that he conveyed that evening really stayed with me and helped to set me on a path to service.

speaker: clinton
text: I also remember that he spent the last day of his life in Memphis, fighting for dignity and higher pay for working people.

speaker: clinton
text: And that is our fight still. We have to get the economy working and incomes rising for everyone, including those who have been left out and left behind. We have to keep our communities and our country safe.

speaker: clinton
text: We need a president who can do all aspects of the job.

speaker: clinton
text: I understand that this is the hardest job in the world.

speaker: clinton
text: I'm prepared and ready to take it on and I hope to earn your support to be the nominee of the Democratic Party and the next president of the United States. [applause]

speaker: moderator
text: Thank you. Senator Sanders, your opening statement, sir.

speaker: sanders
text: Thank you. As we honor the extraordinary life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., it's important not only that we remember what he stood for, but that we pledge to continue his vision to transform our country.

speaker: sanders
text: As we look out at our country today, what the American people understand is we have an economy that's rigged, that ordinary Americans are working longer hours for lower wages, 47 million people living in poverty, and almost all of the new income and wealth going to the top one percent.

speaker: sanders
text: And then, to make a bad situation worse, we have a corrupt campaign finance system where millionaires and billionaires are spending extraordinary amounts of money to buy elections.

speaker: sanders
text: This campaign is about a political revolution to not only elect the president, but to transform this country.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator, thank you. [applause]

speaker: moderator
text: And Governor O'Malley, your opening statement, sir.

speaker: omalley
text: Thank you. My name is Martin O'Malley, I was born the year Dr. King delivered his "I Have A Dream" speech.

speaker: omalley
text: And I want to thank the people of South Carolina, not only for hosting our debate here tonight, but also for what you taught all of us in the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Mother Emanuel Church.

speaker: omalley
text: You taught us, in fact, in keeping with Dr. King's teaching, that love would have the final word when you took down the Confederate flag from your state house; let go of the past and move forward.

speaker: omalley
text: Eight years ago, you brought forward a new leader in Barack Obama to save our country from the second Great Depression. And that's what he's done. Our country's doing better, we're creating jobs again.

speaker: omalley
text: But in order to make good on the promise of equal opportunity and equal justice under the law, and we have urgent work to do, and the voices of anger and fear and division that we've heard coming off of the Republican presidential podiums are pretty loud.

speaker: omalley
text: We need new leadership. We need to come together as a people and build on the good things that President Obama has done.

speaker: omalley
text: That's why I'm running for president. I need your help, I ask for your vote, and I look forward to moving our country forward once again.

speaker: omalley
text: Thank you.

speaker: moderator
text: All right. And Governor, thank you. [applause]

speaker: moderator
text: All right, to our first question, now. The first question, I'll be addressing to all of the candidates.

speaker: moderator
text: President Obama came to office determined to swing for the fences on health care reform.

speaker: moderator

speaker: sanders
text: So, what my first days are about is bringing America together, to end the decline of the middle class, to tell the wealthiest people in this country that yes, they are going to start paying their fair share of taxes, and that we are going to have a government that works for all of us, and not just big campaign contributors. [applause]

speaker: clinton
